sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten picture postcard from Jenny Kornfeld to Moriz Violin, dated September 23, 1909
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Jenny Kornfeld sends Moriz Violin best wishes for recovery, and greetings to Fanny Violin; — her husband (Emil Kornfeld) adds his greetings.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Gebäude; building; Stadttheater; town theater; Eröffnung; opening; Grüße; greetings

tei:opener.tei:note: photograph of Aussig Town Theater, with caption: Photo-Centrale Aussig.

tei:address.tei:addrLine: Am: Herrn K. u. K. Professor M. Violin

tei:opener.tei:salute: Sehr geehrter Herr Professor!Couched in formal style by Jenny Kornfeld ‒ Schenker's future wife Jeanette, who at this date was still living with her husband and children in Aussig. The playfully exaggerated tone suggests that Jeanette is already acquainted with Moriz and his sister Fanny, as from the postscript seems to be true also for her husband, Emil. — This seems to be the first document in Jenny Kornfeld's hand among the Violin papers, and probably also the first that is datable among the Schenker papers. In Schenker's diary for June 30, 1908, while vacationing in St. Anton, he recorded "Mrs. J. K." ‒ apparently the first reference to her in Schenker's hand, implying her arrival ‒ though probably in the company of her family, with whom Schenker is known to have vacationed several times.

tei:div.tei:p: Von unserem l. Dr. Sch. erfahre ich daß Sie nicht wohl sind, was ich aufrichtig bedaure. Hoffentlich bessern Sie sich bald.
in pencil:Schrecklich!Although editorially marked as in an unknown hand, this is quite possibly in the same hand as the postscript, which itself is likely to be that of Emil Kornfeld.
Umstehendes Gebäude ist unser neues Stadttheater über denen Eröffnung Sie vielleicht gelesen haben.
Ich bitte Sie Frl. Schwester meine Grüße zu bestellen u. grüße Sie selbst

tei:postscript.tei:p: in pencil:Herzlichst grüßt, Ihr Emil KfldThe reading "Kfld" (followed by a flourish) is open to question, but since Schenker uses this very compression himself when referring in his diary to Emil Kornfeld, that perhaps adds credibility. Since the handwriting is unlike that of Jenny, it seems inescapable that this was written by Emil Kornfeld himself.

tei:opener.tei:note: photograph of Aussig Town Theater, with caption: Photo-Centrale Aussig.

tei:address.tei:addrLine: To: Imperial and Royal Professor M. Violin

tei:div.tei:p: I hear from our dear Dr. Schenker that you are unwell. I truly regret this and hope you will soon feel better.
The building overleaf is our new Town Theater, about the opening of which you may perhaps have read.
Please convey my best wishes to your sister and I send

tei:closer.tei:salute: my most cordial good wishes to you yourself

tei:postscript.tei:p: in pencil:Emil Kornfeld sends you most cordial greetings.
